entry.title: Re: Good Recipient cannot generated in mvt 311 when using...
entry.content:
Why the Goods Recipient field Is empty in MIGO 311 with WM Sloc could be due to the following:-

  • When you post a 311 transfer posting between storage locations that are Warehouse Management (WM)-enabled, SAP triggers WM-specific processes (e.g., transfer requirements and transfer orders). These processes do not use the Goods Recipient field from MIGO;  instead, they rely on WM logic for tracking and accountability. In WM-managed locations, the recipient is typically not relevant at the IM level because the goods are tracked by bin and transfer order.
  • Once MIGO posts the 311 movement, SAP creates a Transfer Requirement (TR) and expects the warehouse team to process it via LT06 or LT12. These transactions do not carry forward the Goods Recipient field from MIGO.

If the Goods Recipient field is critical for your process (e.g., for audit or tracking), couple of workarounds are there

  • Consider using non-WM-managed storage locations for 311 postings; this allows full control over IM-level fields.
  • If WM must be used add a custom field or enhancement to capture the Goods Recipient in the Transfer Order (TO). Use user exits or BAdIs (e.g., MWMTO001) to pass the value from MIGO to TO.

entry.title: Re: Source of data for Settlement Doc Pricing
entry.content:
You have raised two questions

  1. Does Split Criteria Control Field Population in Settlement Items?
  2. Do You Need to Append WBRP or Can Pricing Read from Business Volume or CDS?

To answer your first question, Yes, partially. The split criteria in the condition contract settlement process determines which fields from the business volume base are transferred to the settlement item (WBRP). If a field (e.g. Customer Price Group) is part of the split criteria, it will be copied into the settlement item. If it‚Äôs not part of the split criteria, it won‚Äôt be available in WBRP; and therefore, not usable in pricing unless you enhance the structure. So yes, split criteria is the key control for populating fields in settlement items.
To answer your second question, Standard pricing reads from the settlement item (WBRP); not directly from the business volume table or CDS views. So if your pricing condition (e.g. RCS1 or RCA1) uses fields like Customer Price Group or Material Price Group, those fields must be present in WBRP. Otherwise, the access sequence won‚Äôt find the condition record.

What you can do is to append WBRP with the required fields (e.g. KUNNR, MATKL, PRGRP). Include those fields in split criteria so they are populated from business volume. Enhance the business volume CDS view if you need to extract additional fields during volume determination

entry.title: Complex Multi-Rater Performance Rating Overall Calculations in SAP SuccessFactors Integration Center
entry.content:
This blog outlines a solution for calculating complex performance ratings involving multiple rater roles within SAP SuccessFactors PMGM. The methodology leverages a combination of Table Reports, SFTP, Metadata Framework (MDF), and Integration Center, demonstrating the advanced capabilities of the platform‚Äôs native tools without requiring custom development. I hope that it could inspire you about the power of combining these tools.

Background

Take below calculation logic as an example:

The standard performance rating calculation logic in SuccessFactors is insufficient when faced with certain complex requirements. The primary challenges addressed by this solution include:

  • Multiple Rater Influence: The overall rating calculation must incorporate input from various rater roles (e.g., Manager, HR, Matrix Manager), with specific weighting for each role being sourced directly from Employee Central.
  • Dynamic Goal/Competency Content: The performance form contains a variable number of goals and competencies, which are organized into multiple distinct categories.
  • Role-Specific Ratings: The final report must reference section-level ratings for each distinct rater role. And the role amount vary in different form.
  • Lack of Identifiers: Standard reporting tools and APIs do not provide a direct identifier for the specific role of the user who entered a rating, making it difficult to differentiate between inputs.

Implementation Details

The solution is implemented in three main stages: data export, data ingestion, and calculation.

Step 1: Exporting Raw Rating Data

The first step is to extract the raw rating data from the performance forms.

  1. Report Creation: Two separate Table Reports are created‚Äîone for goal ratings and one for competency ratings. Both reports are configured with an identical data structure to ensure consistency. The key fields include:
    • Subject User ID
    • Form Template ID
    • Document ID
    • Competency/Goal ID
    • Competency/Goal Other Rating (the rating value)
    • Competency/Goal Weight
    • Competency/Goal Other Rating Owner User ID (the rater's ID)
    • Form Start Date
    • Section ID
    • Section Name
  2. Data Filtering: Filters are applied to the reports to exclude irrelevant data, such as deleted forms, unrated items, and non-essential form sections.
  3. Scheduled Export: A daily scheduled job is configured to export the reports as CSV files to a designated SFTP server. It is important to note that Table Reports are essential for this step; the Integration Center cannot be used directly to export all ratings from a performance form as it requires a specific Form Data ID to be provided as a parameter.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Step 2: Ingesting Data via Integration Center

Next, the exported data is consumed and processed.

  1. File Consumption: The SFTP server will contain daily goal and competency files, each appended with a date suffix.
  2. Integration Setup: Two separate Integration Center jobs are configured to process these files. Each job maps the fields from its respective CSV file to a custom MDF object.

Note: The integration must be configured to use the Upsert Single operation. This is mandatory because the process updates a parent-child MDF object structure, and this operation ensures data integrity for both the parent and child records within a single execution.

Step 3: Executing Calculations via MDF Business Rules

The core logic of the solution resides in business rules attached to the custom MDF object. When the Integration Center upserts data into the MDF object, onSave rules are automatically triggered to perform the calculations.

The MDF object is structured with parent and child levels to properly organize the data for calculation. The key fields and logic are detailed below:

MDF Object Field Description

ParentexternalCodeMaps to Subject User ID.
ParentexternalNameMaps to Document ID.
ParenteffectiveStartDateMaps to Form Start Date.
ParentOverallRating, etc.Stores the final calculated ratings for each role and the overall score.
ChildexternalCodeA composite key created from ItemID + RaterUserID.
ChildRoleThe calculated rater role (e.g., EM, EX) based on Job Relationships.
ChildCategoryMaps to the Section Name from the performance form.
ChilditemRatingThe weighted item rating, calculated as Rating * Weight.

Key Business Rule Logic

Several critical business rules drive the automated calculations:

  • Role Type Identification: This rule determines the rater's role by cross-referencing the Rating User ID from the form with the employee's Job Relationship data in Employee Central. A condition is included to prevent the role from being cleared if a rater's job relationship has changed since the form was completed.

  • Role-Specific Section Rating: The solution calculates the section-level rating for each rater role (e.g., Goal Section Rating for the Manager, Competency Section Rating for HR). This is achieved using the Sum of Collection Field Values() function, which aggregates the itemRating values from the child object, filtered by the rater's Role and Category.

  • Overall Rating Calculation: The final, overall rating is computed by applying the appropriate weighting for each rater's section scores. Since these weight proportions are sourced from Employee Central, the business rule includes conditional logic to apply different calculation formulas based on the configuration stored in EC for the subject employee.

Conclusion and Further Applications

This solution successfully automates a complex, multi-rater performance rating calculation by integrating several standard SAP SuccessFactors tools. The final calculated data, stored within the custom MDF object, becomes readily available for analysis and reporting through Canvas and Story reports.

Furthermore, because the performance form's unique Document ID is stored in the MDF object, a subsequent integration can be configured. We could import the calculated overall rating back into the corresponding field on the in-progress performance management form, fully closing the loop on the process and ensuring data consistency across the system.

entry.title: Re: ARM Process Issue
entry.content:
This behavior is likely due to how SAP ARM determines follow-up activities based on material master settings, Return reason, Inspection outcome and customizing in LO-ARM (Advanced Returns Management).
SAP may attempt to create SD2 if it interprets the scenario as a free replacement delivery, even if the refund type is set to Replacement. This can happen if the replacement material is not properly maintained or determined, the inspection result or return reason maps to a follow-up activity that includes SD2 and there‚Äôs a fallback logic in ARM that defaults to SD2 when replacement fails.

  • Review your ARM Customizing Sales and Distribution > Advanced Returns Management > Define Follow-Up Activities. Here, check the mapping of return reasons and inspection codes to follow-up activities. Ensure that replacement is correctly assigned and SD2 is not inadvertently triggered.
  • Ensure the replacement material is correctly maintained in the return order. If the material is missing or invalid, SAP may default to SD2 or fail silently.
  • Even if SLG1 is empty, try SM13 for update failures and ST22 for dumps

  • what usage data is collected (meaning automatically collected data about how users use and navigate the system)
  • what technical data is collected (meaning automatically collected device information such as IP address, browser type and version, time zone setting and location, browser plug-in types and versions, operating system and platform)

entry.title: Re: Split FU (item or header level) using web service
entry.content:
Hi @Wolfgang_Mayer1 

Thanks for clarifying your scenario.

Based on the standard SAP S/4HANA 2023 TM, there's no delivered web service to split an existing Freight Unit.

Based on the data available the only way to fully automate FU splitting is through custom development, typically by:

  • Creating a custom OData/SOAP endpoint or enhancement BADI.
  • Leveraging the BOPF service manager to invoke a split action on the /SCMTMS/FU business object (either at item or header level).

This approach re-produces the ‚ÄúChange Freight Unit‚Äù UI behaviour programmatically.

I hope this helps provide the information required. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to declare both quantity and billing percentage in SAP PS for SD billing?
entry.content:
Hello SAP experts,

I‚Äôm working on a BTP project using SAP PS and SD. The client wants to trigger SD billing from project milestones, which is a standard scenario. However, they also want to declare the actual quantity to be billed (e.g., 3 pallets of tiles, 5 bags of cement), not just rely on the milestone percentage.

In the standard milestone billing setup, the milestone only allows you to enter a percentage, which SAP then uses to calculate a partial billing quantity or value in SD.

Is there a standard way in SAP PS to declare both:

  • the milestone percentage (to track progress)

  • and the actual quantity to be billed (to reflect real physical work done)?

I've considered confirmation of activities (CNF) or material consumption (movement 261), but I'm looking for a way to integrate this directly into the milestone billing logic, or at least a standard-compatible workaround.

Any insights, configuration tips, or clarification on SAP standard limitations are very welcome.

Thank you!

entry.title: Re: SAP IBP Inventory - EOQ Key Figures questions
entry.content:
Hi @Andrei_Lupu 

Thank you for reaching out with your EOQ scenario. Let me walk you through it.

Based on SAP IBP best practices and system behaviour, here‚Äôs how you should populate the key figures:

  • Enter the demand forecast per planning bucket (e.g., 100,000 pcs per week).
  • Use the holding cost per unit per week, not the total. For example, $0.10 per piece/week.
  • Enter the average cost per replenishment cycle (e.g., $1,500 per order), including fixed freight and GR costs.

Do ensure sure all values are aligned to your weekly time bucket, and that the ‚ÄúTime Varying‚Äù flag is correctly enabled in all 3 key figures to reflect seasonal or period-based variation.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Error when upload LTMC PIR with condition in SAP Publ...
entry.content:
Hi @imel_99 

Thank you for the detailed screenshots and explanation.

You seem to be encountering this issue during the LTMC upload of a Purchasing Info Record (PIR) with pricing conditions, where:

  • Manually created PIRs automatically assign PPR0 (Net Price).
  • However, in your LTMC upload, when using PPR0, the system expects PNP0 instead, causing errors unless you include PNP0.

Based on your screenshots and logs, the issue arises because the LTMC upload is using a pricing procedure (ZAB001) that expects condition type PNP0 instead of PPR0 for Net Price.

In contrast, your manual PIR creation likely uses a different procedure or configuration that defaults to PPR0.

To resolve this, the are two available options:

  • Adjust pricing procedure ZAB001 to use PPR0 if that aligns with your standard.
  • Or include PNP0 in your LTMC uploads if PNP0 is the expected net price condition.

You can review this under SPRO √† Define Pricing Procedures √† ZAB001 and check which conditions are mandatory.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Shared Resource Scenario in PPDS
entry.content:
Hi @Debasis_Nanda 

Thanks for sharing the details. This is one of the classic cases of modelling shared secondary resources in PP/DS.

You can define the hoppers as a multiresource with a total capacity of 6. Then you can use it as a finite secondary resource across both packing lines.

Each operation can then consume a portion of the hoppers (e.g., 2 or 4), and PP/DS will only schedule when the total hopper usage across both lines stays within 6.

It's best to configure this using bucket-based finite scheduling and maintain usage per order operation in the PDS. This allows you to simulate and balance hopper usage while scheduling based on order priority and setup times.

I hope this provides you the necessary details you need. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Can we set multi scaled conditions in SAP TM Rate table?
entry.content:
Hi @LINGLINGLING_CN 

Yes, this requirement can be fulfilled in SAP TM by combining per-FU FOs with aggregated pricing logic.

You‚Äôll need to:

  • Configure your rate table with From Location To Location, and Calendar Day as condition keys
  • Enable charge aggregation in your charge type (set calculation rule to Rate Based, aggregation mode to Day, base = Weight)
  • Define a grouping strategy in your charge calculation sheet to aggregate FO weights by lane and shipping day.

This setup allows you to keep 1 FU = 1 FO while still applying daily consolidated pricing per lane/weight.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Regarding to BADI /SCWM/EX_CORE_PTS_NBIN_NRM To allow...
entry.content:
Hi @MahmoudElshall

Thank you for your question

Based on your description it can be confirmed that this is expected behaviour. Please note that once you implement /SCWM/EX_CORE_PTS_NBIN_NRM, SAP no longer applies its standard bin split logic automatically. Hence why a different approach is required.

To enable automatic bin splitting again, you need to manually handle the split inside your BADI implementation:

  • Loop over available bins
  • Check remaining capacity for each
  • Distribute quantity accordingly in ET_FINAL_BIN

Alternatively, you could explore using BADI /SCWM/EX_CORE_PTS_STRATEGY for more control.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Last movement in WH Monitor
entry.content:
Hello @sylwiac &  @hannes_mack 

@sylwiac 

This is a very valid requirement and one that‚Äôs come up in several warehouse optimization projects.

Although SAP EWM does not provide this out-of-the-box, you can implement it by:

  • Querying /SCWM/ORDIM_C or /SCWM/ORDIM_H to get the last WT confirmation date for each product in a bin.
  • Filtering for storage types that represent PSA, Quality, or Work Center zones.
  • Building a custom monitor method or Z-report that shows stock along with ‚Äúlast movement date‚Äù and calculates the days since last movement.

This approach works well for identifying forgotten inventory and cleaning up long-idle stock.

 

@hannes_mack 

You are right, this feature exists in WM/SRM but not natively in EWM. However, it can be added by enhancing the Warehouse Monitor (/SCWM/MON).

My suggestion is to:

  • Join /SCWM/QUAN and /SCWM/ORDIM_C to get the latest putaway confirmation per bin/product.
  • Use a custom monitor method to calculate the number of days since that movement.
  • Display this value in a new column within the Stock node.

You can use the monitor enhancement framework or alternatively build a report that provides this insight to warehouse supervisors.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Storage bin lock during WT creation after complete pr...
entry.content:
Hello @gerardbuitelaar89 

Thank you for your question.

This is a standard behaviour in EWM when you are using Addition to Existing Stock strategy in a bulk storage type. If a WT is created to a bin but not yet confirmed, the system locks the bin to prevent over-allocation.

Even with the HU check off and capacity check set to 4, EWM still locks the bin for the following reasons:

  • There's an open WT for that bin
  • The system uses a default bin locking mechanism

To resolve this, my suggestion is to:

  • Check for unconfirmed WTs in /SCWM/MON.
  • Confirm existing WTs before creating new ones.
  • Alternatively, consider adjusting your putaway rule or WT creation logic to allow parallel usage of the same bin.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Friends concept in ABAP OO
entry.content:
First you have to understand the concept of an abstract factory pattern. In such a pattern, there is a family of classes, that execute the business logic (they are called products), and then there is a family of factories - their only task is to produce the right class of product. We don't want any developer to create product on their own. Which means that this has to be impossible:

data(product) = new lcl_product_b( ).

The only way to block producing it is to have lcl_product_b created privately:

CLASS lcl_product_b DEFINITION CREATE PRIVATE
  INHERITING FROM lcl_product.
ENDCLASS.

Then the question comes: If it's created private, then how can it be created if it doesn't have a factory method? The answer is: have an abstract factory that is befriended with it.:

INTERFACE lif_factory DEFINITION.

METHODS: create_product RETURNING VALUE(result) TYPE REF TO lcl_product.
ENDINTERFACE.

CLASS lcl_product DEFINITION 
  ABSTRACT 
  CREATE PRIVATE
  FRIENDS lif_factory.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_product_b DEFINITION
  INHERITING FROM lcl_product. "now product_b is private and also gives it's friendship to all class implementing the factory
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_factory_abs DEFINITION.
PUBLIC SECTION.
interfaces lif_factory.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_factory_b DEFINITION INHERITING FROM lcl_factory_abs.
PUBLIC SECTION.
methods lif_factory~create_product.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_factory_b IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD lif_factory~create_product.
    result = new lcl_product_b( ). " I can do it only because family of factories are befriended to the family of products
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

 

Please mind, that if anyone uses this complex pattern to create one class, they will burn in developer's hell, or will reincarnate as a "html developer".  This pattern is to be used to create a family of various products, where there are many variations of creating such a family. In any other case, the "factory method" pattern is a much better choice.

For example, you need to create a family with:

  • mother
  • father
  • son
  • daughter
  • cat

you create an abstract factory lcl_family_factory (I'm skipping interface for simplicity and laziness üòâ

CLASS lcl_family_factory definition abstract.
methods:
create_mother returning value(result) type ref to lcl_mother,
create_father returning value(result) type ref to lcl_father,
create_son returning value(result) type ref to lcl_son,
create_daughter returning value(result) type ref to lcl_daughter,
create_cat returning value(result) type ref to lcl_cat.
ENDCLASS.

This class does nothing, but then you create concrete factories:

  • lcl_nubian_family_factory
  • lcl_mayan_family_factory
  • lcl_inca_family_factory
  • lcl_babylonian_family_factory
  • lcl_slavic_family_factory
  • lcl_viking_family_factory

Now if I want to create a family, I will use one of the concrete factories to get all the products (all members of a family). This way I will always get a consistent family. If I produced each member separately, there would be a risk of my error, so that a Mayan family has a Slavic lynx instead of a puma - imagine how improper would that be. To prevent such mistakes, all the product classes are CREATE PRIVATE and the only way to produce them is through the factory.

Normally in ABAP there's no need for abstract factory, unless you produce your own product.

entry.title: SAP Digital Manufacturing 25.08 Release enhancements and new capabilities
entry.content:
See my personal highlights of SAP Digital Manufacturing 25.08 Release below:

* Subject to change
* This blog post is Work In Progress and will be constantly updated in the upcoming days during the release cycle, so make sure you come back often to check the updates. 

Do you like this content? Please live a Kudos!

Dynamic Topics in Subscriptions and in the Publish MQTT Message Service

You can use free text to define the topic where your MQTT message will be published when creating indicator and message type subscriptions in the Manage Automatic Triggers app. A similar feature also applies to the Publish MQTT Message service of the Design Production Processes app. You can use parameters, variables, and expressions, in addition to free text.

To use this feature, make sure you are using Production Connector on Windows or Production Connector on edge, both with version 2.6.0 or higher. 

More information:

  • Available Services and Subprocesses
  • Manage Subscriptions
  • Create a Subscription

Data Collection

  • Added List to the parameter Type field in the Manage Data Collection app. You can use the List type to choose the required data field for your parameter from the list of data fields displayed in the Select Data Field page through a value help.
  • For Boolean type parameters, you can set a default True / False value while creating the parameter in the Manage Data Collection app. The set value is selected by default and is displayed in the segment button in the Data Collection POD plugin.
  • Certain special characters are supported while defining the Data Collection Group Name, Version, and Parameter Name in the Manage Data Collection app.

Bulk Component Add Integration

Previously, if you didn't configure the collaboration link COLLABORATION_SFC_COMPONENT_ADD, the assembly of non-EWM components was integrated with your ERP system during SFC completion. This happened through the Production Order Yield Confirmation message and/or the Production Order Scrap Confirmation message if you configured the collaboration links COLLABORATION_ERP_YIELD_CONFIRMATION and/or COLLABORATION_ERP_SCRAP_CONFIRMATION. You can still use this integration scenario where the 261 goods movement is part of the yield or scrap integration message.

Now, if you configure the collaboration link COLLABORATION_BULK_COMPONENT_ADD with the collaboration directive ERP_BULK_COMPONENT_ADD, the assembly of these components integrates with your ERP system during SFC completion through the Production Order Bulk Component Add message. The Production Order Yield Confirmation and Production Order Scrap Confirmation messages only integrate the yield and scrap data, respectively. So, in this scenario, which lets you bulk add components, the 261 goods movement data is no longer contained in the yield or scrap messages.

You need to set up the following elements for this integration scenario:

  • COLLABORATION_BULK_COMPONENT_ADD collaboration link / ERP_BULK_COMPONENT_ADD collaboration directive in the Manage Collaboration Links app.

  • Bulk Add Production Order Component integration flow in SAP Cloud Integration

More information: Manage Collaboration Links and Manage Collaboration Directives

Configuring Production Processes for Packing

You can set up the system to trigger production processes during packing when you choose Add or Pack in the Packing List plugin in the POD. To do this, assign production processes to one or more of the following configuration options of the Packing List plugin in the POD Designer app:
  • Production Process Before the Pack Action
  • Production Process After the Pack Action
  • Production Process After the Add Action
 
More information: Production Processes Executed During Packing

Custom Fields in the Operation Activity List

In POD Designer, you can configure the Operation Activity List plugin to display custom fields defined for routing operations in the operation activity list of your POD.

More information: Operation Activity List

Enable SFC-Based Scheduling

You can enable SFC-based scheduling in the Manage Business Settings app, allowing you to plan and track of operations for each SFC in the Dispatching and Monitoring app.

More information: Scheduling.

Learn more about SFC-Based Scheduling at:

  • SFC-Based Dispatching in Resource Orchestration
  • SFC-Based Dispatching in REO: Granular Production Scheduling and Process Industry Support

Filter Operation Activity List by Resource

Added a configuration called Filter by Resource to the Operation Activity List plugin. When set to On, operation activities are filtered by a specific resource, if provided. The default value is Off.

More information: Operation Activity List

Usability Improvements for the Manage Orders App


Improved the user interface of the Manage Orders app:

  • In the Adapt Filters menu, you can access the search functionality.

  • The release and execution statuses are semantically color-coded.

More information: Manage Orders

Order Report

You can filter records based on the material description using the Material value help.

More information: Order Report

SFC Report

  • You can filter records based on the material description using the Material value help, batch number, storage location, and components.

  • You can view batch number and storage location in the General section of the SFC details page.

  • The Components tab in the SFC details page is enhanced to display non-BOM components in addition to the BOM components.

More information: SFC Report

Manufacturing Data Objects (MDOs)

The following events are supported by the SFCProductionEvents MDO:

  • SFC_HOLD
  • SFC_HOLD_RELEASED

The HoldComment attribute has been added to the SFCProductionEvents MDO.

Cloud Event Deprecations

In the upcoming 2602 release, several cloud events will be deprecated in the business rules in the Manage Automatic Triggers app. New events have been introduced in this release to replace the deprecated ones. The following list displays the deprecated events along with their substitutes.

This deprecation announcement is effective starting from the 2602 release. The new events are available from the 2508 release.

  • Existing Event: SFC Started - v2
    Substitute Event: SFC Started - v3
  • Existing Event: SFC Yield - v1
    Substitute Event: SFC Yield - v2
  • Existing Event: SFC Split - v1
    Substitute Event: SFC Split - v2
  • Existing Event: SFCs Merged - v1
    Substitute Event: SFCs Merged - v2
  • Existing Event: SFCs Relabeled - v1
    Substitute Event: SFCs Relabeled - v2
  • Existing Event: SFCs Serialized - v1
    Substitute Event: SFCs Serialized - v2
  • Existing Event: SFC Operation Activity Started - v1
    Substitute Event: SFC Operation Activity Started - v2
  • Existing Event: SFC Operation Activity Completed - v1
    Substitute Event: SFC Operation Activity Completed - v2

Starting from the 2602 release, the SFC Created - v1 cloud event will be deprecated and removed from the Manage Automatic Triggers app. Update any business rules that use this event by replacing it with Order Released - v3.

More information: Manage Automatic Triggers.

Specific Business Services Deprecation

Starting from the 2602 release, the below business services will be deprecated. In the Manage Automatic Triggers app, the following business services will no longer appear as options in the Business Service dropdown menu under the Business Rules tab.

  • Complete Operation Activity - v1
  • Complete Phase - v1
  • Complete SFC - v1
  • Final quantity confirmation on completed operation activity - v1
  • Merge SFC - v1
  • Production Change - v1
  • Quantity Confirmation - v1
  • Relabel SFC - v1
  • Serialize SFC - v1
  • Set quantity SFC - v1
  • Split SFC - v1
  • Start Operation Activity - v1
  • Start Phase - v1
  • Start SFC - v1

Deprecation of the Overlay Authoring Tool and Associated Plugins

The Overlay Authoring Tool has been deprecated, along with the following associated plugins:

  • Line Monitor Fill Color
  • Line Monitor Image Overlay

Changes to Identity and Access Management

We're continuing to improve role template definition by restricting view access to apps that show data not required by certain personas. We're making these changes to improve overall usability.

The following default PODs are no longer included on the default Fiori launchpad for all personas:
  • Work Center POD (Default)
  • Order POD (Default)
  • Operation Activity POD (Default)
  • Post Production Reporting POD (Default)
  • Line Monitor POD (Default)
In addition, we're removing the following role templates:
  • Automation_Technical_User
  • Plant_Manager
  • Global_Regional_Manager
  • Alert_Monitor_User

For detailed information, refer to SAP Note 3618884.

Change Production

To make sure that activity confirmation data is covered in production change scenarios, we've introduced the ActivityConfirmationCopy flag in the Production Order Download (LOIPRO05 V2) integration workflow.

By default, this flag is set to 'false'. If set to 'true', the activity confirmation data is copied from operation activities belonging to the old routing to the new routing after the production change has taken place.

More information: Updating Orders After the Release for Production Order (Custom XSLT)

New and Changed API Endpoints

Data Collection

  • POST /datacollection/v1/nonwip/uploadFile: You can use this endpoint to upload and securely store non-WIP data collection files during the data logging process.
  • The GET /measurements endpoint in the Data Collection API must be used only for normal data collection requirements. For non-WIP data collection, you must use the GET /nonwip/measurements endpoint in the Standalone / Non-WIP Data Collection API.
  • The following fields are added to the GET /groups, POST /groups, PUT /groups and GET /sfc/groups endpoints in the Data Collection API:
    • defaultValueName: Allows you to set a default true / false value while creating a data collection parameter.
    • listTypeDataField: Allows you to choose the required data field for your data collection parameter from the list of data fields.
  • The V1 and V2 versions of the Setpoint Activities API are decommissioned. Start using the V3 version of the API.

Labor

  • POST /labors/shift-assignment: This endpoint allows production supervisors to assign specific shifts and optional work centers to the workforce within a plant for a defined date range. More information: Labor.

  • GET /labor/v1/LaborSkills: This OData V4 API endpoint fetches the skillsets of a workforce under a production supervisor‚Äôs scope. More information: Labor.

Setpoint Activities

Added the enableStrictFilter header parameter as an optional parameter to the GET /find endpoint in the Setpoint Activities API. You can now specify the way filters are applied to the setpoints.

More information: Setpoint Activities

Shop Floor Control Production Activities

Added the parameters includeSFCDetails and sfcStatuses to the Shop Floor Control Production Activities API.

The includeSFCDetails parameter is available for the GET /worklist/orders endpoint, and allows you to control if SFC details are retrieved for each order. When includeSFCDetails is set to true, SFC details are retrieved. When it is set to false, no SFC details are retrieved.

 
The sfcStatuses parameter allows you to filter results by SFC status for the following endpoints:

  • GET /worklist/sfcs

  • GET /worklist/orders

  • GET /worklist/sfcs/$count

  • GET /worklist/orders/$count

More information: Shop Floor Control Production Activities and https://api.sap.com/api/sapdme_sfc/resource/Production_Details

Inventory

You can clear inventories for given plants and inventory IDs by using the following endpoint of the Inventory API:
  • POST/api/v1/inventories/clear

    The quantity on hand for specified inventories is set to zero once they're cleared.

You can conduct specific quantity filtering of the stock quantity on hand by using the quantityOnHandFilter field and the following endpoint of the Inventory API:
  • POST/api/v1/inventories/advancedQuery

You can use the bomComponentSequence field in the following endpoints of the Inventory API:

    • POST /inventory/erpGoodsReceipts
    • POST /inventory/ewmGoodsReceipts
    • GET /inventory/goodsReceipts/summarize

      The bomComponentSequence field allows you to precisely identify BOM components of different types (for example, normal, co-product, and by-product) while supporting consistent goods receipt integration with ERP and EWM. This allows you to avoid confusion when the same material has been set up as normal type of BOM component and also as a co- or by-product.

More information: Inventory

And much more! See What¬¥s New for more details.

 
* Subject to change
* This blog post is Work In Progress and will be constantly updated in the upcoming days during the release cycle, so make sure you come back often to check the updates. 
 
Do you like this content? Please live a Kudos!
If you have any questions, please check SAP Community Q&A Area, or comment down below.

Thanks,
Manoel Costa

entry.title: Stream with CAP Node JS
entry.content:
Hello,
I've implemented a very simplistic CAP service that sends a request to a SAP S4 backend system to retrieve a file as a stream ( .../$value)

This a simplified version of my code in the request handler function :

const results = await _sendAxiosHttpRequest(
            {
                method: "GET",
                url: "<service_path>/$value",
                headers: oHeaders,
                responseType: "stream",
                maxContentLength: Infinity,
                maxBodyLength: Infinity
            },
            <my_destination>);
    
 return [{ value: results.data,
           $mediaContentType: results.headers["content-type"],
           $mediaContentDispositionType: results.headers["content-disposition"] }];

As you can see, i send the request using Axios and in debug mode I checked that this request to the S/4 backend is successful.
results.data is an object of type IncomingMessage (which is a readable stream)
The problem is that the response generated by the CAP service contains nothing. It returns an empty response. 
Even the headers "content-type" and "content-disposition" are not set.

Do you have any Idea, why it's not working ?

Thank you for your help üôÇ

entry.title: Re: Cloud ERP & Primavera
entry.content:
Hi there ‚Äî ran into a similar challenge recently while supporting a hybrid cloud ERP setup.

While direct reference cases for S/4HANA Public Cloud + Primavera P6 are limited (especially on the public customer side), most integration scenarios we‚Äôve worked with use middleware like SAP BTP or CPI, leveraging iDocs/XML for schedule and cost data sync. You might also consider intermediate staging via flat files + RFC/ODATA when APIs are too limited on either end.

We had a similar case at Phonexa, integrating multiple SaaS platforms with different data schemas ‚Äî biggest lesson: plan early for data ownership, sync frequency, and fallback handling.

Would also recommend checking SAP Note 2769657 and related threads in the SAP Project Systems tag ‚Äî a few users posted workarounds there.

Hope that helps!

entry.title: Re: CR 2025 Database Login Screen?
entry.content:
In your DSN add the password so CR can use it from the DSN info.

Designer will never save the password in the RPT file, for security reasons.

You have to log on before CR prompts for the parameter.

Another way is before opening a report Log on to the database and then open your report, it should prompt... but you have to do that every time you open the Designer

entry.title: Re: CR 2025 Database Login Screen?
entry.content:
ODBC connection DSNs do not allow saving the password - not that I can see, anyway. You can enter a password, but that is only used to finish the configuration and test the connection.

Normally, I do enter the password every time I open a report for editing.  My users run the reports with a tool that relies on the CR runtimes.  In that case, we feed the password to the runtimes in the background.

I actually think that I may have mistakenly clicked the "Trusted Connection" box when logging on to the server in CR; apparently it really doesn't like that?

entry.title: Re: CR 2025 Database Login Screen?
entry.content: Look under the Advanced button, ah, the would be why, If using Trusted you need to set it to true in code in the connection property bag otherwise it will prompt since the info is not there.

Hello @adityayadav18 

In S/4HANA Public cloud, linked POBs from contracts are only supported with Optimized Contract Management, not the classic version. To enable this, activate scope item 2ME (Central Procurement) and configure BRFplus rules via the Manage Rules for Central Purchase Contracts app.

Outlining the Different Solutions for Contract Management in SAP -SAP Learning

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Smooth Transition Ahead: SAP Enable Now Migration from SAP BTP Neo to SAP BTP, Kyma runtime
entry.content:
Hi,

There are three things that must be done to minimize the chance of issues from the migration:

1. Modify SSO, which you mention
2. Whitelist the IP address of the new Enable Now servers.  The IP addresses of the servers are included in the email notifications sent about the migration
3. Update the CORS setting in the Manager Server Setting screen.  Refer to this SAP Note for more information on this topic

Regards
Shane

entry.title: Re: Source of data for Settlement Doc Pricing
entry.content:
Hi @Dforway1, 

To add on top of what @Lakshmipathi already explained. 

1. Yes, the split criteria configuration is one way to capture the information from the business volume source data to the Settlement document header or line item item. Others data are also populated because of master data (material, vendor, customer..), such as product hierarchy, material group. 

2. Some data are also not present in the tables WBRK/WBRP but will be determined in the pricing determination based on the data of the header/item level in standard, such as Customer hierarchy (the one of the Bill-to of the Settlement per default), Customer group, Material group 1/2/3/4/5...

There is not 1 solution to be provided to your pricing problem, I would say it depends of your requirements. 
Sometimes split criteria will be necessary, sometimes maybe a simple setup in Transfer Manager, or maybe a more complex logic to be built in Transfer Manager via Source Class, or a mix of all of them. 

 

Regards, 
Gauthier VICTOR

entry.title: Re: Growth Rebate in Condition Contract
entry.content:
I confirm the approach of @ygongalov15 , that's the way to go for Growth scenario as standard CCM will not support out the box Growth with the standard scenario. 
It will require a bigger enhancement and logic if the Growth scenario is not that straightforward (e.g. period if not always 12 months, Growth is not based on $...) 

Regards, 
Gauthier VICTOR

entry.title: BAdI (MRM_WT_SPLIT_UPDATE) that is not released in S/4HANA Cloud Private edition
entry.content:
Hi all,

As per my knowledge, the "Tier 2 wrapper" concept is primarily designed for exposing non-released SAP APIs (like BAPIs or Classes) in a way that allows them to be used within the ABAP Cloud framework (Tier 1) while ensuring upgradeability and compliance with the Cloud model. Therefore, non-released BAdIs are generally handled in Tier 3, utilizing classic ABAP development.

Could you please correct me if I am wrong? I would appreciate it if you share your experiences on non-released BAdIs in S/4HANA Cloud Private edition.

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: Issues Debugging SAP MDK on Windows with Android Emulator
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm facing a persistent issue while trying to debug my SAP MDK application locally on Windows using an Android emulator. The debug session starts correctly and hits breakpoints, but it terminates immediately whenever I type anything in the Debug Console within VS Code. I‚Äôd really appreciate help in understanding and resolving this behavior.

In addition to that, when I try to run the "MDK Attach on Android" debug configuration in VS Code, the application is not automatically (re)installed on the emulator with the updated bundle. I need to run the application in "MDK Launch on Android" mode to install the app, which breaks the expected debug flow. I've tried use the both modes to debug.

Debugger Steps

  1. Open the MDK project in Visual Studio Code.

  2. Run the Build Task (Ctrl+Shift+B) to generate the latest metadata.
  3. Start the application using the debug configuration (e.g., ‚ÄúMDK: Debug on Android‚Äù).
  4. Set a breakpoint inside a .js rule or action file.
  5. Once the app launches in the Android emulator, the debugger correctly pauses at the breakpoint.
  6. However, as soon as I type any command or expression in the Debug Console, the entire debug session terminates unexpectedly.

This makes it impossible to inspect variables or evaluate expressions dynamically during debugging.

Development Environment

  • Operation System: Windows 11 Pro Edition x64
  • Version: 24H2
  • SO Compilation: 26100.4770
  • Android SDK 35
  • Android SDK Build-tools 35.0.1
  • Java development Kit 17.0.14
  • Node 20.19.0
  • Native Script 8.9.2
  • Android Studio + SDK installed and configured
  • VS Code + MDK Extension  installed and configured

Steps Taken

  1. Installed the MDK SDK locally and executed create-client.cmd to generate the project.
  2. Verified environment variables:
    - ANDROID_HOME
    - JAVA_HOME
  3. Ran `tns doctor` successfully (no errors).
  4. Started the project using the SAP MDK VS Code extension
  5. The app launches on the emulator and hits the debugger line inside a .js script.
 

What I've Already Tried

  • Updated and adjusted launch.json with different "trace", "sourceMaps", and "watch" settings.

  • Reinstalled NativeScript CLI and Android SDKs.
  • Tried running VS Code in both Admin and normal modes.
  • Updated all VS Code extensions.
  • Tested with different emulators (x86, x86_64).

entry.title: Multi-Tenant Audit Logging Fails for Subscriber Tenants (401 Unauthorized) in SAP CAP on BTP
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I'm facing an issue with multi-tenant audit logging in my SAP CAP application deployed on BTP. Audit logging works fine for the provider tenant, but fails with 401 Unauthorized errors for subscriber tenants.

Environment Setup

  • Platform: SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry)

  • Framework: SAP CAP (Node.js)

  • Architecture: Multi-tenant SaaS with MTX sidecar

  • Services:

    • XSUAA (application plan)

    • Audit Log Service (premium plan)

    • CAP audit logging (@cap-js/audit-logging v1.0.0)

Issue Details

  • Provider Tenant: ‚úÖ Works perfectly

    • Tenant ID: xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx

    • Audit logging successful

  • Subscriber Tenant: ‚ùå Fails with 401 Unauthorized

    • Tenant ID: yyyyyyyy-yyyy-yyyy-yyyy-yyyyyyyyyyyy

    • Error: 401 Unauthorized - Bad credentials

Manual Testing

Provider tenant:

curl -H "x-zid: xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx" ... ‚Üí 200 OK (token returned)

Subscriber tenant:

curl -H "x-zid: yyyyyyyy-yyyy-yyyy-yyyy-yyyyyyyyyyyy" ... ‚Üí 401 {"error":"invalid_client","error_description":"Bad credentials"}

Questions

  1. Is this expected behavior? Does the Audit Log Service premium plan only allow token fetching for the provider tenant?

  2. Do I need special configuration for cross-tenant access to the audit log service?

    • I tried "authorities-inheritance": true in xs-security.json but it didn‚Äôt help.

  3. What‚Äôs the recommended multi-tenant pattern for audit logging in CAP?

    • Separate Audit Log instances per subscriber?

    • Centralized logging under provider tenant only?

    • Any documented way to enable cross-tenant usage?

Thanks in advance for your support! üôè

entry.title: Re: Can not reach IAS admin page - How to add new IAS adm...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

As mentioned in KBA 3446655, in order to add new IAS admin in SAP for Me, the user needs to be a Super Administrator or Cloud Administrator for that installation.

Currently your S-user does not have sufficient authorizations at the moment.

Could you pls kindly check the super user/cloud admin list in the My Important Contacts page, and then contact your super user or cloud admin to add new IAS admin per KBA 3446655?

If possible, you can also ask your super user or cloud admin to set your S-user as the new super user or cloud admin by copying authorization feature as introduced in KBA 1614304.

Once you become the super user or cloud admin, you are also able to add the new IAS admin on your side.

Hope the above information helps to clarify. 

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

Technically, S/4HANA will show BEx usage ony if they are using Embedded BW. But to double check, go totransaction SE16, and table RSDDSTAT_OLAP:

  • For BEx Analyzer / Workbook usage:
    • Use selection ‚ÄúBEX‚Äù as STEPTP field and ‚Äú3200‚Äù  as EVENTID.
    • Number of entries > 0 show the usage of BEx Analyzer / Workbooks in the system.

Regards

entry.title: Leveraging SAP Joule for Performance & Goals Management: Exact Prompts for Maximum Productivity
entry.content:
SAP Joule, the generative AI assistant built into SAP SuccessFactors, is transforming how organizations manage Performance & Goals (PMGM) activities. With Joule‚Äôs natural language interface, managers and employees can interact directly with their performance data. Driving speed, accuracy, and engagement. Here‚Äôs how you can make the most of Joule, with concrete prompts you can use right away.

 

1. What Can Joule Do for PMGM?

Joule bridges the gap between traditional HR processes and user-friendly digital experiences, empowering you to:

  • Access and update goals

  • Navigate and complete performance reviews

  • Give and receive feedback in real time

  • Manage team calibration, analytics, and more

2. Try These Exact Prompts With Joule

Below are ready-to-use prompts you can enter right into Joule to access, update, or analyze PMGM data:

Goal Management

  • ‚ÄúShow me all my current performance goals.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúUpdate the status of my goal ‚ÄòIncrease Q3 Sales‚Äô to 80% complete.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúAdd a comment to my goal ‚ÄòImprove customer satisfaction‚Äô: ‚ÄòCompleted training on new CRM.‚Äô‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúList my team‚Äôs goals for this quarter.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúHelp me cascade my goal ‚ÄòLaunch New Product‚Äô to my direct reports.‚Äù

Performance Reviews & 360 Feedback

  • ‚ÄúOpen my performance review form.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúWhat is the status of my 360 review?‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúShow me feedback I‚Äôve received in my performance review.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúWho on my team hasn‚Äôt submitted their performance reviews yet?‚Äù

Continuous Performance Activities

  • ‚ÄúCreate a new activity: ‚ÄòCompleted lead generation workshop.‚Äô‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúAdd an achievement for ‚ÄòClosed major client deal‚Äô to my performance record.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúView all feedback I‚Äôve given this year.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúRequest feedback from John Smith on my collaboration skills.‚Äù

Team Management & Calibration

  • ‚ÄúShow me my team‚Äôs performance ratings distribution.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúList employees in my team who are ready for promotion.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúStart a talent calibration session for my department.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúGenerate a summary report of my team‚Äôs goals progress.‚Äù

Analytics & Insights

  • ‚ÄúShow me a dashboard of team goal completion rates.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúWhat percentage of my team met their goals last cycle?‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúGive me insights on performance trends over the past year.‚Äù

Other Practical Prompts

  • ‚ÄúRemind me to submit my self-appraisal by Friday.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúExplain the 9-box grid to me.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúHelp me find the company‚Äôs goal library.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúHow do I assign a new goal to my direct report?‚Äù

3. Best Practices to Drive Value

  • Encourage managers and employees to experiment with these prompts for day-to-day PMGM tasks.

  • Incorporate common prompts in onboarding or training materials to boost adoption.

  • Use prompts to keep review cycles on track with reminders and reporting.

  • Harness dashboard and analytics prompts for sharper, data-driven decisions.

4. The Big Payoff

Using SAP Joule with the right prompts brings:

  • Immediate access to the right performance data and actions

  • Consistency and transparency in performance management

  • Engaged, self-sufficient managers and employees

  • More productive, agile, and collaborative talent processes

Try out these prompts in Joule today and unlock a new era of intelligent, conversational performance management in your organization!
